awd_titl_txt: BPC-AE: Widening Participation in Computing Research via Deepening Mentoring Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
The computing and tech fields have not seen adequate participation from people who identify as female, Black/African American, Hispanic/Latino, Native American, Hawaiian, Alaskan, Asian Pacific Islander, and people with disabilities.  The fundamental issues the project offers potential benefits to education, society and establishing evidence for the experience of different demographic groups in computing. The Computing Research Association’s Committee on Widening Participation’s (CRA-WP) mentoring programs proposed support education and diversity of the computing workforce which ultimately benefit society as a whole. of the computing professoriate. These activities have been very successful at encouraging diverse undergraduate and graduate students in the past.

The Computing Research Association's Committee on Widening Participation in Computing Research (CRA-WP) plans to grow its mentoring programs with three main goals:1) Mentoring for re-entry into computing research through non-traditional pathways; 2) Encouraging, tracking, and evaluating mentoring pathways through their programs to improve retention; and 3) Growing a pool of leaders through mentor mentoring to improve their scale and reach. Alumni tracking will also help characterize medium and long term impacts on underrepresentation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Computing Research Association’s Committee on Widening Participation in Computing Research (CRA-WP) provides mentorship, career development, and research opportunities to support students, early-career researchers, and professionals in computing. From 2022 to 2024, CRA-WP led several programs, including the Career Mentoring Workshop (CMW), Grad Cohort for Women, Grad Cohort IDEALS, Distributed Research Experiences for Undergraduates (DREU), and Distributed REsearch Apprenticeships for Master’s (DREAM). These initiatives have contributed to advancing research expertise and strengthening workforce development and career pathways in computing.

Intellectual Merit

CRA-WP’s programs have enhanced research skills, career preparedness, and professional networks for individuals at different career stages. These initiatives contribute to knowledge growth, leadership in computing research, and the development of a well-prepared research community.

Strengthening Research and Technical Expertise

  • The DREU program provided undergraduate students with hands-on research experience, allowing them to work with faculty mentors on real-world computing problems.
  • Participants reported increased confidence in conducting research, summarizing results, and applying to graduate programs.
  • Over 40% of DREU participants expressed a greater likelihood of pursuing graduate education after the program​.

Graduate Student and Early-Career Development

  • The Grad Cohort for Women (GCW) and Grad Cohort IDEALS programs supported 252 graduate students (131 in GCW, 121 in IDEALS), helping them:
    • Develop research communication skills.
    • Strengthen computing identity and self-efficacy.
    • Gain professional networking opportunities to support career progression​​.
  • Participants reported greater confidence in completing their degrees and advancing in research careers.
  • DREAM supported students who transitioned into computing from other disciplines, helping them navigate graduate coursework and research expectations. Participants expressed increased interest in pursuing a PhD but also highlighted a need for greater awareness of funding options and doctoral pathways.

Career and Leadership Development

  • The CMW served 116 professionals, including 72 early-career and 44 mid-career participants, with 20% from industry and national labs.
  • Attendees gained insights into career planning, leadership skills, and strategies for professional advancement.
  • Mid-career professionals particularly benefited from sessions on securing funding, managing research teams, and preparing for leadership roles​.
  • DREAM introduced participants to computing career pathways in both academic and industry settings. Participants gained confidence in professional networking and research communication, skills essential for long-term career success.

Broader Impact

Beyond academic research, CRA-WP’s programs have influenced workforce readiness, mentorship practices, and career pathways in computing and related fields. These efforts ensure that individuals have the resources and guidance needed to succeed in research-intensive careers, industry roles, and leadership positions.

Expanding Workforce Development and Industry Collaboration

  • 20% of CMW attendees were from industry and national labs, demonstrating the program’s role in bridging academia and industry.
  • Participants gained practical skills in negotiation, leadership, and professional networking, making them more competitive for senior roles in research and technology​.
  • DREU students gained exposure to computing careers in both academia and industry, helping them explore multiple career paths​.

Building Sustainable Mentorship Models

  • CRA-WP’s structured mentoring approach serves as a model that can be applied across other STEM disciplines.
  • Participants reported that mentoring relationships helped them gain clarity on career decisions, improve leadership skills, and navigate academic and industry environments successfully​​.
  • The mentorship model used in Grad Cohort and DREU programs has influenced how universities and research organizations support students and professionals through structured career development initiatives.

Long-Term Career Impact and Knowledge Dissemination

  • Many former CRA-WP participants have gone on to secure leadership roles, contribute to major research initiatives, and mentor the next generation of computing professionals.
  • CRA-WP’s programs have been highlighted in computing research news, academic conferences, and career development discussions, expanding their influence on STEM education and workforce strategies.
  • These efforts help ensure that future computing professionals have the skills, knowledge, and support necessary to contribute to technological advancements and innovation.
